Article.Abstract: T cells recognize antigen by formation of a trimolecular complex in which the T-cell receptor (TCR) recognizes a specific peptide antigen within the groove of a major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecule. It has generally been assumed that T-cell recognition of two distinct MHC-antigen complexes is due to similarities in the three-dimensional structure of the complexes. Here we report results of experiments examining the crossreactivity of TCRs recognizing the myelin basic protein peptide MBPp85-99 and several of its analogs in the context of MHC. We demonstrate that single conservative amino acid substitutions of the antigenic peptide at the predominant TCR contact residues at positions 91 and 93 totally abrogate reactivity of specific T-cell clones. Yet, when a conservative substitution is made at position 91 concomitant with a substitution at position 93, the T-cell clones regain reactivity equivalent with that of the original stimulating peptide. Thus, the exact nature of the amino acid side chains engaging one TCR functional pocket may change the apparent selectivity of the other predominant TCR functional pocket, thus suggesting a remarkable degree of receptor plasticity. This ability of the TCR-MHC-peptide complex to undergo conformational changes provides a conceptual framework for reconciling the apparent paradox of the extreme selectivity of the TCR and its remarkable crossreactivity with different MHC-peptide complexes.
Article.ArticleTitle: Complementary mutations in an antigenic peptide allow for crossreactivity of autoreactive T-cell clones.
Article.Affiliations: Laboratory of Molecular Immunology, Brigham and Women's Hospital, Boston, MA, USA.
Article.ArticleChemicalList: HLA-DR Antigens;Myelin Basic Protein;Oligopeptides;Receptors, Antigen, T-Cell

Journal.Title: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America
Journal.MedlineTa: Proc Natl Acad Sci U S A

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: The MS patient had well-characterized early relapsing remitting disease with minimal disability with at least two exacerbations within the previous 24 months and positive lesions on MRI at the time of blood drawing. The details of the patient were described in the cited reference: Ota, K et al. (1990). Nature. 346, 183-187. [PMID: 1694970].

AssayInformation.AssayComments: The epitope specific T cell clone could not recognize peptides in which there was a substitution at position 93 and showed minimal reactivity to peptides in which position 91 was altered.

EpitopeRelatedObject.RelatedObjectType: The epitope is an analog of:

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Positions 91 and 93 were two predominant contact sites for the TCR, any of the peptides with amino acid substitutions at position 93 (including the conservative lysine substitution) and 91 (including the conservative phenylalanine substitution) could not be recognized by the epitope specific T cell clone.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: The MS patient had well-characterized early relapsing remitting disease with minimal disability with at least two exacerbations within the previous 24 months and positive lesions on MRI at the time of blood drawing. The details of the patient were described in the cited reference: Ota, K et al. (1990). Nature. 346, 183-187. [PMID: 1694970].

AssayInformation.AssayComments: The substitution of an arginine for a lysine at position 93 allowed for both conservative and nonconservative substitutions at the other predominant TCR contact residue 91. However, with a tyrosine at position 91, only minimal reactivity was observed to peptides not having an arginine at position 93.
